title: Will any member of China's Politburo resign, be suspended, or be removed from the Politburo in 2016?
preds: No reports so far, that sound anything like this one: BEIJING, Oct. 29 2015 (Xinhua) -- The fifth plenary session of the 18th Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee on Thursday [last year, October 2015] ... to revoke the membership of 10 former officials, including Ling Jihua. ... taken advantage of his posts to seek profits ... http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-10/29/c_134763526.htm Nothing this year.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
china has a record of removing officials for corruption etc so it's possible, but unlikely

Epoch Times (analysis & opinion), December 1, 'China’s Xi Jinping Paves Political Transition With Anti-Corruption Drive': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2191503-chinas-xi-jinping-paves-political-transition-with-anti-corruption-drive-2/
Clips from article:
"Beyond the Party?
Through the anti-corruption campaign, Xi Jinping has placed himself in a position that allows for all kinds of future political scenarios that would be impossible under Jiang Zemin, whose power stemmed from corruption and kleptocracy.  
Already, Chinese scholars have suggested the possibility of China’s taking on a presidential system of governance.
In November, the Xi leadership rolled out a pilot program for a new state anti-corruption body that answers to the Chinese legislature, and not the executive branch. Having this body answerable to the legislature may anticipate a change in the structure of the Chinese regime, with the Party no longer being in charge of everything.
If Xi takes the anti-corruption campaign to its logical conclusion, the inadvertent outcome might be a post-communist China." Comments: An eventual end to the Politburo? Adjusting down for the passage of time.
Running out of time, and not much happening.
Adjust for the passing of time and consensus

Epoch Times, November 16, 'Exclusive: China’s Anti-Corruption Chief Will Be Exempt From Forced Retirement': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2186725-exclusive-chinas-anti-corruption-chief-will-be-exempt-from-forced-retirement/
Clips from Epoch article:
"‘Rather the Devil Than Wang’
Xi and his supporters agreed that “Wang Qishan must remain in office,” despite the retirement age, because he’s their best candidate to head anti-corruption investigations and disciplinary reforms, according to the source.
Xi launched the anti-corruption campaign shortly after taking office, and vowed to crack down on both low and high-ranking officials who abuse their positions for personal gain. Xi also appears to be using the campaign, which is very popular with the Chinese people, to eliminate the faction of Jiang Zemin, the Party elder responsible for fostering pervasive corruption in China.
Wang was placed as head of the anti-corruption agency in 2012, and has overseen the arrest of more than a million officials—more than 150 of whom were high-ranking Party cadres in the government, state-run enterprises, and the military.
Officials are said to prefer meeting “the Devil” rather than Wang, a gaunt-looking man with a steely gaze. Under Wang’s watch, officials who were considered “untouchable,” like the former Politburo member Bo Xilai and the powerful security czar Zhou Yongkang, were probed and handed over for prosecution." Comments: Xi's enforcer.  BBC News, November 7, 'Why did China axe Finance Minister Lou Jiwei?': http://www.bbc.com/news/business-37869769
Clips from BBC article:
"Xi vs Li?
So should this move be seen as a way to push out the vocal government critic, in favour of a more malleable and accommodating comrade? Or the physical manifestation of the power struggle between President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang?
It's impossible to say for sure. China's political decisions are rarely transparent and whether this was a move by President Xi Jinping to move someone into a position of power who shares his view of the economy, we'll probably never know.
And there's an argument that as Mr Lou turns 66 next month, enforced retirement beckoned anyway.
But what many China observers are saying is that President Xi is consolidating his power ahead of next year's party congress - and while he does that, his focus on reforming the economy may not be topmost on his mind." Comments: Xi appears to be a patient man. Adjusting down.
Adjusting for the shorter time horizon
If there were any dissenters to be purged, would have happened just after the recent meeting where they endorsed a core supreme leader

Stratfor, October 25, 'Watching for Signs of a Political Triumph by Xi': https://www.stratfor.com/geopolitical-diary/watching-signs-political-triumph-xi Incremental adjustment down for the passage of time.
Down 15% since nothing seems to be happening related to the meeting this week. As others have pointed out, most are scheduled to move on next year.

Interesting article on the subject from Reuters. Seems that the hunt has moved on from the big beasts. Still time for something to happen however. 'Still, after an initial shock-and-awe phase of the battle which saw dozens of top tigers investigated and jailed, including the once fearsome domestic security chief, Zhou Yongkang, there are now fewer senior officials being caught.' http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-china-corruption-idUKKCN12K0BQ

Okay, all in. They now even have 1960s-type of public trials but on TV; quite relentless, I say.

"But as China prepares to enter a “selection year” under the leadership of a very unconventional president, Xi Jinping, there is increasing speculation he may try to dispense with the retirement convention entirely."
https://www.ft.com/content/09cc1044-8f77-11e6-a72e-b428cb934b78
Shortly before or a bit after the plenum scheduled for 26-29 October, somebody will be made an example of.

Good NYT article on chinese leadership succession: Xi Jinping May Delay Picking China’s Next Leader, Stoking Speculation
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/05/world/asia/china-president-xi-jinping-successor.html
The Chinese president, Xi Jinping, appears prepared to defy the Communist Party’s established script for transferring power and delay the designation of his successor until after a party congress next year, unsettling the party elite and stirring speculation that he wants to prolong his tenure.
“Even the amount of consolidation of power so far may have raised hackles,” said Susan Shirk, the chairwoman of the 21st Century China Program at the University of California, San Diego. “I don’t think Xi will want to further raise alarms about Putinesque intentions.” If he is pressed to name someone, a younger Politburo member like Sun Zhengcai, the party secretary of Chongqing, could gain support. The world may not know who has won and lost until Mr. Xi introduces his new team after the congress ends late next year. "Predicting what happens depends on “whether or not you think the de facto rules and norms of elite succession will hold,” said Evan S. Medeiros, the former senior director for Asian affairs in the National Security Council under President Obama. “If not, predicting outcomes is a crapshoot.” "The dilemma for Mr. Xi is that the politicians who will remain in the top echelons after next year’s retirements do not have long experience working with Mr. Xi or the right set of postings in provincial and central government, according to several experts and people who speak to senior officials. But the rising provincial leaders considered closest to him lack the experience to be taken seriously as the next national leader in waiting."
COMMENT: The final quoted paragraph sustains my probability: Xi wants to keep the current team as long as possible while he searches for replacements.

Reuters, September 30, 'Exclusive: Xi set to consolidate power in China by curbing Communist Youth League': http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-politics-league-exclusive-idUSKCN1200OL
Clips from article:
"Among those on the Standing Committee, only Xi, 63, and Premier Li Keqiang, 61 – who is a member of the Youth League faction - will not have reached retirement age by the time of next year's congress. They are both widely expected to retain their No. 1 and 2 spots on the committee, the sources and diplomats said. The other five will most likely retire based on what has happened at previous congresses. If the three potential Youth League candidates – Vice President Li Yuanchao (no relation to Premier Li), Vice Premier Wang Yang and Guangdong provincial party boss Hu Chunhua (no relation to former president Hu) – were elected at the Congress, the Youth League faction would have a majority on the body and that would be unacceptable to Xi, the sources said. All three are currently members of the Politburo. These people said it wasn’t immediately clear whether Xi is planning any other moves against the Youth League faction. At least one of the faction's candidates is expected to get elected whatever Xi's efforts, the sources said." Comments: Youth League. Three names. Who'll pick the short straw in the next 60 days? Affirming forecast.
Lowering based on passage of time. I think it may happen but not until next year.

There is only one quarter left. Changes in the politburo are not that common bar corruption scandals. I'm not aware of any rumours of allegations against any of the members at this point. There is an official reshuffle planned in 2017 anyway, so there is less need for Xi to force a change in 2016

» Xi is trying to prevent the Communist Youth League faction from dominating the party’s seven-member Standing Committee during the 19th congress next year, .... If the three potential Youth League candidates – Vice President Li Yuanchao (no relation to Premier Li), Vice Premier Wang Yang and Guangdong provincial party boss Hu Chunhua (no relation to former president Hu) – were elected at the Congress, the Youth League faction would have a majority on the body and that would be unacceptable to Xi, the sources said. All three are currently members of the Politburo. These people said it wasn’t immediately clear whether Xi is planning any other moves against the Youth League faction. At least one of the faction’s candidates is expected to get elected whatever Xi’s efforts, the sources said. Xi wants to promote those most loyal to him so that he can push through reforms to buoy the slowing economy and handpick a successor to ensure his legacy, they said. .... “Xi is 100 percent out to stop the Youth League faction. He wants his own people in place.” « 
http://atimes.com/2016/09/xi-set-to-consolidate-power-by-curbing-communist-youth-league/
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-corruption-idUSKCN12006D Is this meaningful? Former boss jailed - is more coming?
@dkc Hot phase started, session next month.
Adjusting for time. No mention in the following article about any major moves as yet. https://www.ft.com/content/48abb5dc-7e3b-11e6-8e50-8ec15fb462f4
Already September. If indictments were going to happen, they would have earlier in the year, since Politburo members will be standing down anyway in 2017.

China's anti-corruption campaign serves the purpose of getting rid of leaders that are both corrupt as well as opponents of Xi Jinping; he's already succeeded in removing the biggest obstacles to his goals, so there is little reason to remove any current Politburo members. Additionally, all major CPC meetings for the year have been held.

A  good recent backgrounder paper on China´s anti-corruption campaign and how it relates to factional struggles and elite/Politburo concerns. Shared by Bill Bishop´s Sinocism newsletter (highly recommended). https://sinocism.com/?p=11679 Rescuing Autocracy from Itself: China’s Anti-Corruption Campaign
http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2835841 "Faced with the severe threat from within, the incumbent top leadership is taking a collective action in support of Xi Jinping. The anti-corruption campaign is essentially a political purge to re-establish the internal control of the authoritarian party."
"However, there is no evidence that suggests the incumbent top leaders are providing shelters for their factional members. In other words, most factions within CCP are taking the same side as Xi Jinping in the anti-corruption campaign and hence the intra-elite struggle in the top CCP has been limited. ...  So what exactly is the threat? In this article we propose that the way some specific factions selected and cultivated members has threatened the stability of the Party’s autocracy, which is the real reason why Xi’s anti-corruption campaign can obtain support from others in the top leadership ... By looking into the investigation decisions, we found that city leaders promoted via unhealthy channels, especially through tolerating local corruptions are more likely to be investigated. A quick glance does suggest that the anti-corruption campaign seems like a crackdown on certain factions. However it doesn’t look like a fight against usurp, but against the erosion of the authoritarian regime from within, which is an effort to bring order out of chaos within the party."

Bloomberg, September 11, 'Mayor’s Investigation Shakes Up China’s Political Chessboard': http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-12/mayor-s-investigation-shakes-up-china-s-political-chessboard Adjusting down for the passage of time.
NO, next year. Xi too busy with SCS cruising

Adjusting to the consensus as it seems unlikely at present that anything will happen. Some movement though in the lower reaches of the establishment suggests there's still some jostling to be done: https://www.ft.com/content/52871ca4-7a35-11e6-ae24-f193b105145e

The Huang Xingguo removal, said to trigger Politburo power plays in 2017 http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2018440/top-tianjin-officials-exit-may-trigger-politburo-power reveals also the slow workings of power that  in effect in my mind lower the odds of this question resolving as a yes.  Succinctly put, Politburo positional moves must take into account both who exits and who enters. While the field remains contested and uncertain on the possible entrants; with several vacancies possibly opening up in the Politburo for 2017, a replacement move  this year, unless considered urgent, will be weighted against the need to develop (arguably scarce) new cadres and give them time to prove themselves.

BEIJING, Sept. 10 (Xinhua) -- Huang Xingguo, mayor of north China's Tianjin Municipality, is being investigated for suspected "serious disciplinary violations," ... http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-09/10/c_135678295.htm
Adjusting for time. Interesting article for reference: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-12/mayor-s-investigation-shakes-up-china-s-political-chessboard

Down 10% to be more under the consensus. I expect it might happen, but can offer very plausible reasons that things will just "go along."

Please look at the following table, I use the so called stable period starting from 11th to 18th politburo and I found 53% of member took one time, 36% took two times, and only 8% of members can last for 3 times. Considering of 2016 is a key year of middle election, the chance of member to be rolled-off would be high.But Mr. Xi also would like a stable year of 2016 to fight against bad economy, the stability of politburo is also important. So 70% would be my guess.

Why Xi Jinping’s bid to put ‘power in a cage’ must go to the very top
Coming up with clear rules to govern the members of China’s Politburo – and their families – presents the leadership with one of its biggest tests yet
http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/2009570/why-xi-jinpings-bid-put-power-cage-must-go-very-top Not sure when these rules will kick in effect, and how toughly they will be applied.

There is some fast shuffling going on, as there often is at this point in the cycle.  The Big Kahuna seems committed to consolidating his authority in the fairly near future.  Anybody left on the Politburo who is not among his BFFs should keep luggage packed and passport up to date.

Some of these folks are term-limited next year anyway and may refer to their resignations as "retirement," apparently not contemplated by the wording of this Q.  One hopes that premature retirements will be counted as resignations, but one is never sure around here.

Newsweek (opinion), August 20, 'CHINA’S XI JINPING IS EYEING A RETURN TO SUPREME POWER': http://www.newsweek.com/chinas-xi-jinping-eyeing-return-supreme-power-dictator-491894
Clip from article:
"...... As the late political scientist Tang Tsou put it, the struggle for power in China is, above everything, a game of winner-take-all. Like Mao and Deng before him, Xi is playing not to compromise, but to win." Comments: The PRC is at a pivotal point in it's history. Xi knows it. He most likely has a vision of where he wants to take the country. Besides, who's really going to oppose him? 
NYT, April 21, 'China’s President, Xi Jinping, Gains a New Title: Commander in Chief': http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/22/world/asia/china-xi-jinping-military-commander.html?_r=0
Clips from NYT article:
"Mr. Xi, who is general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, is also chairman of the Central Military Commission, which runs the country’s armed forces. After his visit on Wednesday, a new title was unveiled in the state and party news media: commander in chief of the joint battle command center.
Like his predecessors, Mr. Xi generally wears an olive-green Mao suit when carrying out his Central Military Commission duties. But on occasion he has also worn camouflage fatigues when meeting People’s Liberation Army troops, as he did on Wednesday along with the rest of the staff of the joint battle command center.
“It’s very carefully crafted,” Mr. Raska said of Mr. Xi’s appearance. “It shows he’s part of the P.L.A. and the convergence of policy and the military.”  Dropping 5 basis points for the passage of time.

Rumors now abound within the party about whether he will be replaced as premier in next year’s reshuffling of key party posts. Messrs. Xi and Li are the only two members of the seven-man Politburo Standing Committee—the top leadership body—not due to retire. http://www.wsj.com/articles/discord-between-chinas-top-two-leaders-spills-into-the-open-1469134110

If I were running an anti-corruption show in China, finding a Politburo member to finger would be right up there with shooting fish in a barrel.   The Big Kahuna knows this, and will either finger or blackmail somebody as a result.  For the purpose of this Q, of course, it matters which.
Gathering of party elite to plan direction for coming years happening now - changes could happen before end of the year.

Based on 7 up 8 down; Li and Chunhua are both eligible to return to the next politburo. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/04/world/asia/china-communist-youth-league.html?_r=0

Raising slightly on the analysis in this article, particularly the closing paragraph: 'The Politburo decided in late June on new rules for party discipline that hold officials responsible for being rejected by the people or damaging the party's political standing, giving Xi even more power for his anti-corruption campaign. Party members debate in hushed tones which major figure the president will target next.' http://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Policy-Politics/Chinese-leaders-jockey-for-power-at-secret-meeting?page=1 Given that we still have a long time to run on this, and information on internal manoeuvres will be limited,  I'm going to maintain my position for now.
China is midst of political purge.

The culmination of these maneuvers could be the removal of Premier Li Keqiang, the one Hu ally on the seven-member Politburo Standing Committee, the pinnacle of Chinese politics. Mr. Li would normally serve a 10-year term through 2022, but rumors are flying that Mr. Xi will force him to retire at the Party Congress next year and move other Hu allies into ceremonial positions.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-xi-jinping-ascendancy-1467748121 "Xi, however, a recently introduced set of Party internal disciplinary regulations that could prove to be game changing—the new regulations endanger the senior Party leadership, deepen the scope of Xi’s purge, and provide an authoritative boost to rid the Party of an antagonistic action that is believed to have been obstructing Xi’s authority. On June 28, Xi introduced the “Chinese Communist Party Accountability Ordinances” at a meeting of the Politburo—an important conclave comprising 25 of the regime’s top officials—which he chaired. In particular, the plenum would focus on the internal political conduct of leading party institutions and cadres, especially members of the Central Committee, its Politburo and the innermost Politburo Standing Committee, Xinhua said."
https://chinadigitaltimes.net/2016/07/cadres-face-stricter-rules-party-discipline-becomes-plenum-focus/

Edging up slightly on the basis of the article below: http://thediplomat.com/2016/07/chinese-ex-general-gets-life-in-prison-for-corruption/ 'Continued anti-corruption efforts will reportedly be a focus of this year’s Central Committee plenum, scheduled for October. The sixth plenum since the 18th CPC Central Committee was formed in 2012, this year’s session will focus on “key issues concerning the comprehensive and strict management of the Party,” including revising regulations concerning intra-Party supervision, according to Xinhua.  The plenum’s focus was announced on Tuesday, a day after Guo’s conviction. “[T]here is the need for writing a set of norms for political life in the Party under the new circumstances,” Xinhua said, citing a statement from the Politburo. Of special note, the new regulations will focus in particular on “senior officials including members of the CPC Central Committee, Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee, and the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee.” ' Referred to again here too: http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/1995182/chinas-cadres-may-face-stricter-rules-revamp-communist

China's anti-corruption campaign got off to a strong start. However, Xi has had a hard time keeping the momentum going. This could indicate internal disputes about the power that he is consolidating. Any form of removal of a Politburo member could be seen by either side as a political move as opposed to an anti-corruption decision.

WSJ (opinion), July 5, 'The Xi Jinping Ascendancy - A winner-takes-all political struggle continues in China.': http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-xi-jinping-ascendancy-1467748121
Clips from article:
'While the “tiger hunt” for top-level cadres may be over, that doesn’t mean Mr. Xi has consolidated power. China’s political struggle continues in other guises. This will make government policies unpredictable and risks conflict spilling out into public view in ways not seen since 1989.
The culmination of these maneuvers could be the removal of Premier Li Keqiang, the one Hu ally on the seven-member Politburo Standing Committee, the pinnacle of Chinese politics. Mr. Li would normally serve a 10-year term through 2022, but rumors are flying that Mr. Xi will force him to retire at the Party Congress next year and move other Hu allies into ceremonial positions.
Attacking rival factions’ right to exist violates a key tenet of Chinese elite politics since Deng Xiaoping’s rise to power in 1979. The top leader has always governed in consensus with other leaders who maintained their own power bases. These factions competed for key positions but did not seek to eliminate each other. This tradition was designed to prevent a repeat of Mao’s purges. Mr. Xi has upended this decision making by consensus and made himself the decider in all policy realms.'
Comments: Li Keqiang. Another name surfaces. Says, he may be eased out next year among others, but..... hey
Raising by 10 basis points.

On whether the Panama Papers are known and cited in China, say in Hong Kong  "... as editor-in-chief of Ming Pao, a muckraking Chinese-language daily, the newspaper contributed investigative work to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists’ (ICIJ) expose on the offshore holdings of China’s elites ... February 2014 when Kevin Lau was brutally stabbed ... His successor was marched out of the office at midnight and told don’t come back ... their latest editor-in-chief, Keung Kwok-yuen, was suddenly fired last month after running a front-page story on local politicians and businessmen named in the Panama Papers. ... press freedom advocate Mak Yin-ting fears that self-censorship may become “endemic” in Hong Kong ..." http://asiapacificreport.nz/2016/06/16/beijings-invisible-hand-felt-as-hong-kong-press-freedom-declines/

The leadership of the Communist Party of China (CPC) on Tuesday adopted a regulation on Party officials’ duty of care. Party officials must be held responsible for serious consequences caused by their negligence or poor work performance, which undermines the Party’s governance and harms the people’s interests, according to a statement issued after a meeting of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee, presided over by Xi Jinping, general secretary of the CPC Central Committee. The new regulation introduced an internal Party accountability mechanism, which can be applied across all levels and divisions, the statement said.

It's the fourth year of the current 18th Central Committee; in 2017, we have another National Party Congress that also starts the 19th Central Committee period.  Based on previous and current members' lifetime (tenure) in the Politbureau, there was 
- a 20.6% probability to leave the PB in the 5th year; 
- a 2% prob to leave in the 3rd year, and 
- a tiny 1.1% to leave in the 2nd year; 
- never in the first year.  The major cutoff year is a member's 10th year in the Politbureau. Only 13% of Politbureau members ever stay longer, namely for 15 years---typically the primus, like Hu Jintao. Based on the 10-year criteria, the 2007-roster are likeliest candidates to leave in 2017. Here they are: - Wang Qishan http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Wang_Qishan|426 (responsible for anti-corruption campaign)
- Wang Yang http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Wang_Yang|2696
- Xi Jinping http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Xi_Jinping|303 (chairman of the military commission)
- Yu Zhengsheng http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Yu_Zhengsheng|315 (the guy for Taiwan affairs)
- Zhang Dejiang http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Zhang_Dejiang|35 (national security)
- Zhang Gaoli http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Zhang_Gaoli|319 (China's guy for greening) Obviously, Xi Jinping is going to stay. Wang Qishan, Yu, and Zhang Dejiang are in the Standing Committee that is typically the end career point---except becoming Chairman of the Central Military Commission, like Hu Jintao and Xi Jinping. So, Wang Yang and Zhang Goali ... Wang Yang may have a bonus as he is almost ten years younger than the others and the CCP has a strict age rule for those close to 70. Mr. Yu, for instance, is a prime suspect for leaving, based on age and length of tenure. Major decisions will happen during the: - 6th plenary session of the 18th Central Commitee, Oct/Nov 2016 - 19th National Party Congress, Oct/Nov 2017
- 13th National People's Congress, March 2018 It's unlikely to see a purge among Politbureau members, especially one and a half year before the Party Congress. The modus is to block Central Committee members from joining the Politbureau; not purging Politbureau members once inside. As I wrote above, 20% or so may leave the Politbureau in the 5th year of membership, that is by the end of 2017. A note on Bo Xilai: Like clockwork, he left the Politbureau in his 5th year. Historical biographies of recently expelled cadres of the Politburo: - 2007 to 2012, expelled in 2012 during tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Bo_Xilai/full
- 2002 to 2006, "sacked" in 2006 during tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Chen_Liangyu - 2007 to 2012, investigation started in 2014 after tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Xu_Caihou
- 2007 to 2012, expelled in 2015 after tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Ling_Jihua|3190
- 2002 to 2012, expelled in 2015 after tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Guo_Boxiong/full
- 2002 to 2012, arrested in 2014 after tenure http://www.chinavitae.com/biography/Zhou_Yongkang/full - 198x to 1989, put under house arrest during tenure ... Zhao Ziyang Details on cadres expelled during tenure:
- http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-07/26/content_6434933.htm

" - http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2012-03/15/c_131468566.htm

Epoch Times, June 15, 'Chinese Regime Is China’s Propaganda Chief Headed for a Fall?': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2093009-is-chinas-propaganda-chief-headed-for-a-fall/
Clips from article:
"Propaganda chief Liu Yunshan is a known loyalist of Jiang Zemin the former Party boss. Before Xi took power, Jiang allowed his loyalists in the Politburo Standing Committee—military vice chairs Xu Caihou and Guo Boxiong, and security czar Zhou Yongkang, to name a few—to have the final say on their respective portfolios. In turn, Jiang’s loyalists are committed to protecting their patron because it allows for the continuation of the political order that he oversees.
Xi seeks real control over the Party, and the only way to do that is by dislodging the Jiang power nexus. He has already purged many of Jiang’s top allies, and assumed control over the Party’s gun through a sweeping military reform. The other key Party organ, the Propaganda Department, seems to be next."
Overseas Chinese-language media have recently carried rumors that Liu Yunshan could be purged, and his Propaganda Department reconstituted." The Guardian, June 20, 'Chinese crackdown aimed at rooting out Xi opponents, says bookseller': https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/20/chinese-crackdown-rooting-out-xi-opponents-hong-kong-bookseller-lam-wingkee
Clips from Guardian article:
"He said Lam’s assertion that he was interrogated by a Chinese special investigative group – the same type of unit as has been used to take down senior party officials such as Zhou Yongkang, a senior politburo member convicted of corruption – was also instructive. “He has confirmed that this case is not the product of some out-of-control local officials in southern China but emanates from the party centre,” Cohen said.
William Nee, a China researcher for Amnesty International, said: “Lam’s allegations would seem to indicate that this is being ordered from almost the highest levels of Chinese government.” Comments: Hmmm, this changes my view somewhat..... An interesting academic paper on the framework of this question: The Rules and Norms of Leadership Succession in China: From Deng Xiaoping to Xi Jinping and Beyond
http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/686141 "What can be said is that important changes will likely occur through institutional processes, and justifications will be supplied on institutional grounds. The expected elite turnover must be maintained one way or another—if the 68 age limit is scrapped, for example, other rules must be established to ensure orderly and expected exits from power. Failing this, changes may be unacceptable to Party elites and the rank and file, and serious institutional failures may lead to paralysis and breakdown of the system as well as a legitimacy crisis. On the other hand, Xi and the fifth generation of leaders also have a chance to improve and consolidate the leadership succession process by establishing more explicit and more binding rules regarding exit, selection, and transition. For example, the straw-poll element in the selection of new leaders can become more institutionalized and even turned into a formal poll. Age limits can be turned into term limits, which are more institutionalized in nature. More institutional space can be created for officials who can no longer serve in leadership posts, such as allowing retired leaders to serve in think tanks. The various Party institutions such as the Party congress, the Central Committee, the Politburo, and the various Leadership Small Groups can be given more clearly defined roles and powers. The Party, as the most fundamental institution in the political system, still has a long way to travel in building its own institutions."

The corruption investigation, and the corruption in China was well known prior to the investigation, and generally ignored, includes  jail or execution and has several reasons for the rise in the investigations. Here are two of them. 
Xi wants to stabilize the economy by standardizing the amount of production of materials and commodities. There has been an over production of material that has led to over construction and  unsold cheaper goods that has pressured an all ready weakening economy. Over production has led to graft. 
Some data has been skewed and over valued. Employee tells manager that production was A and manager tells director that production was B and director tells regional director that production was C and so forth. All are given kickback with the least amount going to the employee  and the government publishes the skewed data for investors. This is why Xi has arrested people on all levels. But also, if a person was an associate of someone who was arrested, particularly a business associate to someone who was an arrested government official, the business associate was probably arrested, unless he or she gave evidence of others who may have been corrupt, and given another sentence or excused. 
But the arrests also gives more power to Xi by removing his enemies or opposition, As the economy slides, the Chinese leadership needs a pharmowitnessed kos, and more are being arrested and it will continue into the politburo once his or her supporters are arrested or too afraid to support the arrested official. We this with Mao and that was not long ago.  In some ways, he is forced to fight the corruption, but it works politically for him in image and ruling. Scapegoats are brilliant for strengthening regimes! Add that to: 1. We have Xi pushing the anti-corruption stance; 2. There is a definitive connection in Panama Papers of few top guns; 3. Look at boz's data, precedents are available; 4. There is public pressure. This is a high likelihood event, IMHO. Opening at 90%
Xi will do what he needs to do to solidify his position, someone will go the question is will they go without  a gun to their head.

Four of the five past Politburos, going back to 1987, have had at least one person dismissed or resign. Each of the previous two Politburos had one person dismissed during the final two years (Bo Xilai in 2012; Chen Liangyu in 2006). Nobody has yet been dismissed or resigned from the current five year Politburo, in power since November 2012. On one hand, we're talking a very low number of incidents of resignations. On the other hand, look at that base rate!
